rev.comment: sorry, but no. these facts are cited by multiple reliable sources, you can't delete them just because they reflect poorly on celebrity politician trump
rev.diff:
Line 218: Line 218:
Since the 1990 U.S. elections, Donald Trump has made contributions to campaigns of both Republican Party candidates (including [[John McCain]], [[Rudolph Giuliani]], [[Newt Gingrich]], and [[George W. Bush]])<ref name=trumpsdonations>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/news/2011/02/donald-trumps-donations-to-democrats.html|publisher=OpenSecrets.org|title = Donald Trump's Donations to Democrats, Club for Growth's Busy Day and More in Capital Eye Opener|first=Zachary|last=Newkirk|date=February 17, 2011}}</ref> as well as Democratic Party candidates (including [[Ted Kennedy]], [[John Kerry]], [[Tom Daschle]], [[Joe Biden]], [[Harry Reid]], [[Rahm Emanuel]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Anthony Weiner]], [[Charles Schumer]], [[Kirsten Gillibrand]], and [[Charles Rangel]]).<ref name=trumpsdonations/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0111/47924.html |title=Hollywood helps Rahm haul in $10.6M - Meredith Shiner |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-21/trump-s-run-for-president-requires-memory-loss-kevin-hassett.html|title=Trump's Run for President Requires Memory Loss: Kevin Hassett|first=Kevin|last=Hasssett|authorlink=Kevin Hassett|publisher=[[Business Week]]|date=February 21, 2011}}</ref>
Since the 1990 U.S. elections, Donald Trump has made contributions to campaigns of both Republican Party candidates (including [[John McCain]], [[Rudolph Giuliani]], [[Newt Gingrich]], and [[George W. Bush]])<ref name=trumpsdonations>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/news/2011/02/donald-trumps-donations-to-democrats.html|publisher=OpenSecrets.org|title = Donald Trump's Donations to Democrats, Club for Growth's Busy Day and More in Capital Eye Opener|first=Zachary|last=Newkirk|date=February 17, 2011}}</ref> as well as Democratic Party candidates (including [[Ted Kennedy]], [[John Kerry]], [[Tom Daschle]], [[Joe Biden]], [[Harry Reid]], [[Rahm Emanuel]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Anthony Weiner]], [[Charles Schumer]], [[Kirsten Gillibrand]], and [[Charles Rangel]]).<ref name=trumpsdonations/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0111/47924.html |title=Hollywood helps Rahm haul in $10.6M - Meredith Shiner |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-21/trump-s-run-for-president-requires-memory-loss-kevin-hassett.html|title=Trump's Run for President Requires Memory Loss: Kevin Hassett|first=Kevin|last=Hasssett|authorlink=Kevin Hassett|publisher=[[Business Week]]|date=February 21, 2011}}</ref>
â
===2012 presidential candidacy===
+
==2012 presidential candidacy, political statements, and backlash==
Trump has said that he is seriously considering running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
Trump has said that he is seriously considering running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
Line 239: Line 239:
===Statements regarding presidential candidates===
===Statements regarding presidential candidates===
â
<!--This section should be kept to notable statements regarding policy issues or notable issues where candidates have responded to each other -->
+
Speaking to an audience in Boca Raton, Florida on April 16, 2011, Trump contended that voter reaction to former United States President [[George W. Bush]]'s performance in office was a reason for the election of his successor [[Barack Obama]], and further that Obama would probably be known as the worst president in U.S. history.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/april/233988/Donald-Trump:-Obama-will-go-down-as-worst-president-in-U.S.-history Donald Trump: Obama will go down as worst president in U.S. history].''Bright House Networks''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
â
Speaking to an audience in Boca Raton, Florida on April 16, 2011, Trump contended that voter reaction to former U.S. President [[George W. Bush]]'s performance was the cause for the election of his successor [[Barack Obama]], and further that Obama would probably be known as the worst president in U.S. history.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/april/233988/Donald-Trump:-Obama-will-go-down-as-worst-president-in-U.S.-history Donald Trump: Obama will go down as worst president in U.S. history].''Bright House Networks''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
  â
Trump has promoted the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories about Obama's citizenship status]] in media appearances, and has received criticism for his position.<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump, birther?|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/51473.html#ixzz1GsPWRHLL|first=Kendra|last=Marr|work=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]|date=March 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name=MacNicol>Glynnis MacNicol, [http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-birther-obama-muslim-video-2011-3 "TRUMP: Maybe Obama's Missing Birth Certificate Says He's A Muslim"], ''[[Business Insider]]'' 30 March 2011</ref> In an [[NBC-TV]] interview broadcast on April 7, 2011, Trump said he would not let go of the issue, because he was not satisfied that Obama had proven his citizenship.<ref name=WashPost4711>{{Cite news|title=Trump goes after Obama on US citizenship, says citizenship questions remain unanswered|date=April 7, 2011|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Washington Post]]|separator=,|postscript=|accessdate=April 7, 2011}}</ref>
+
Trump has promoted the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories about Obama's citizenship status]] in media appearances, and he has received criticism for his position.<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump, birther?|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/51473.html#ixzz1GsPWRHLL|first=Kendra|last=Marr|work=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]|date=March 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name=MacNicol>Glynnis MacNicol, [http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-birther-obama-muslim-video-2011-3 "TRUMP: Maybe Obama's Missing Birth Certificate Says He's A Muslim"], ''[[Business Insider]]'' 30 March 2011</ref> In an [[NBC-TV]] interview broadcast on April 7, 2011, Trump said he would not let go of the issue, because he was not satisfied that Obama had proven his citizenship.<ref name=WashPost4711>{{Cite news|title=Trump goes after Obama on US citizenship, says citizenship questions remain unanswered|date=April 7, 2011|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Washington Post]]|separator=,|postscript=|accessdate=April 7, 2011}}</ref>
â
On April 25, 2011 on [[Anderson Cooper 360]] on [[CNN]], Trump said he wanted Obama to end the issue by releasing a long form Certificate of Live Birth (distinct from the short form Certification of Live Birth, which is Hawaii's prima facie evidence of birth).<ref>{{cite web|title= Obama's Birth Certificate |url= http://urbanlegends.about.com/od/barackobama/a/obama_birth_certificate.htm |last=Emery |first=David |work=About.com |date=March 30, 2011 |accessdate=April 26, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Birtherism: Where It All Began|url= http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0411/53563_Page3.html |work=The Politico |date=April 22, 2011 |accessdate=April 25, 2011}}</ref> Trump received criticism from both the political right and left in the media for his stance.<ref name=Politico33011>{{Cite news|last=Haberman |first=Maggie |title=Bill O'Reilly pounds birther Donald Trump |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/52271.html |date=March 30, 2011|work=Polico.com|separator=,|postscript=|accessdate=April 13, 2011}}</ref>On April 27, Trump held a press conference expressing pride at his role in the release of the long-form of Obama's birth certificate. Obama responded that the nation had more important issues that need attention and releasing the long form of his birth certificate would put the matter to rest.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/27/obama-birth-certificate-r_n_854248.html Obama Birth Certificate Released By White House (PHOTO)].''Huffington Post'' April 27, 2011. Retrieved May 8, 2011.</ref>
+
On April 25, 2011 on [[Anderson Cooper 360]] on [[CNN]], Trump said he wanted Obama to end the issue by releasing a long form Certificate of Live Birth (distinct from the short form Certification of Live Birth, which is Hawaii's prima facie evidence of birth).<ref>{{cite web|title= Obama's Birth Certificate |url= http://urbanlegends.about.com/od/barackobama/a/obama_birth_certificate.htm |last=Emery |first=David |work=About.com |date=March 30, 2011 |accessdate=April 26, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Birtherism: Where It All Began|url= http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0411/53563_Page3.html |work=The Politico |date=April 22, 2011 |accessdate=April 25, 2011}}</ref> Trump has received criticism from both the right and the left in the media for his stance.<ref name=Politico33011>{{Cite news|last=Haberman |first=Maggie |title=Bill O'Reilly pounds birther Donald Trump |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/52271.html |date=March 30, 2011|work=Polico.com|separator=,|postscript=|accessdate=April 13, 2011}}</ref>On April 27, Trump held a press conference expressing pride at his role in the release of the long-form of Obama's birth certificate.
  +   +
In the April 27 press conference, after the birth certificate was released by Obama, Trump questioned whether Obama's college grades were sufficient for Harvard admission and called for the release of Obama's transcripts from Occidental College.<ref>[http://nation.foxnews.com/donald-trump/2011/04/08/msnbc-host-wants-parent-company-fire-trump MSNBC Host Wants Parent Company to Fire Trump] [http://washingtonscene.thehill.com/in-the-know/36-news/9131-weiner-nbc-should-tell-trump-youre-fired Weiner: NBC Should Tell Trump "You're Fired"]</ref><ref name=Schieffer>{{cite news|author=Schieffer, Bob|title=Schieffer: Racism underlying Trump's assertions|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20058072-503544.html|date=April 27, 2011|work=CBS News|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=April 27, 2011}}</ref> Trump's statements were criticized by journalists, commentators and comedians.<ref name=Cina>{{cite news|author=Cina, Mark|title=Who Hates Donald Trump Most in Hollywood Now|date=April 29, 2011|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/who-hates-donald-trump-hollywood-183731|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Miller, Daniel|title=Donald Trump's 'Celebrity Apprentice': Why Only One Advertiser Has Fired Him (Analysis)|date=May 3, 2011|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/donald-trumps-celebrity-apprentice-why-184320|publisher=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name=Schieffer/><ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/05/05/thomas.trump.obama/index.html?hpt=T2 "Trump's disrespect for President Obama"], May 6 2011 via CNN.com</ref>
